title: Film, Video, and American History
subject: HIST

description: Offered in the Beinecke Rare Book Library. The social, cultural, and technological aspects of book publishing, production, and distribution from the fifteenth century to the present. Emphasis on three critical eras and technologies: the Renaissance and the mechanically reproduced book, the nineteenth century and the rise of mechanized printing and mass distribution, and the current digital age, when long-held assumptions about books, publishing, and reading will be examined and far-reaching questions about literacy, distribution, global access and equity, and even cognitive science discussed. The course is taught as a seminar through a series of first-hand encounters with rare manuscripts, books, prints, and other primary sources, from the medieval period through the present day. In addition, several class meetings will take place in other Yale collections that contain objects related to our study of the book as an instrument and agent of social change.  1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.
title: From Gutenberg to Google Books: The Cultural History of Publishing, 1450 to the Present
subject: HIST

description: A survey of major religious debates, battles, and debacles in Europe from the late medieval period to the eighteenth century. Major topics include the Crusades, late medieval heretical movements, the Protestant and Catholic Reformations, the wars of religion, the seventeenth-century witch craze, and the rise of tolerance. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.
title: From Crusade to Enlightenment: Religion and Society in Medieval and Early Modern Europe
subject: HIST

description: Examines the Cold War as a struggle for ideological and geopolitical preeminence, tracing its origins, stagnation, and unexpected end from the perspectives of three worlds: capitalist, socialist and postcolonial. Sources include declassified documents, contemporary fiction and recent secondary reinterpretations, as well as films and field trips. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.
title: The Cold War
subject: HIST

description: Offered in Dubrovnik, Croatia. Multidisciplinary study from antiquity to modernity. Byzantine presence and the remnants of the Roman world; consequences of the schism between Rome and Constantinople; barbarian kingdoms and the medieval city-states; Ottoman incursions and millets; Renaissance and Baroque; beginning of nationalism and modern national integrations; national revolutions, fascism, communism, and post-communist conflicts; secularization of religion; genocide in post-Yugoslav wars. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Dubrovnik, room and board costs in Croatia, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Must be taken in conjunction with SOCY S286. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,050. Course dates: July 2 - August 3.
title: History and Culture of Southeastern Europe
subject: HIST

description: Survey of the history of China, Japan, and Korea from the seventh century to the present. Focus on two separate empires: the Tang and Japanese. Attention to interactions among East Asian regions in the past and today. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.
title: Empires of East Asia
subject: HIST

description: Points of interaction between Islam and nationalism in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries. The evolution of concepts such as clan loyalty, national identity, ethnic differentiation, and religious brotherhood. Case studies include Iran, China, Indonesia, Egypt, Palestine, the United States, Turkey, and Pakistan.  1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.
title: Islam and Nation
subject: HIST

description: Offered in Mombasa, Kenya. Modern history of East Africa, with a focus on health, environment, and society. The rise of Swahili language and culture; slavery and plantation agriculture; colonial regimes, medical discourse, and environmental degradation; agrarian protest and nationalist mobilization; conservation ethics and national parks; female genital cutting; HIV/AIDS; post-independences governments and contemporary politics. This course provides an excellent introduction to East Africa from both academic and experiential perspectives. Students choose HIST or AFST credit. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Mombasa, costs of room and board in Mombasa, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 2 Credits. Yale students may petition for one HU area credit. Tuition: $6,100. Course dates: June 14 - July 21.
title: History of East Africa
subject: HIST

description: The emergence of internationalism during the final years of World War I and its immediate aftermath, and the descent toward obsolescence of the empire model in world politics. Responses to Woodrow Wilson's peace diplomacy and the League of Nations; the Russian revolution and the subsequent upheaval across Eurasia; the struggles for Indian, Irish, and Czech independence; the birth of modern nationalism in Asia. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session B: July 9  - August 10.
title: World Politics 1917-1919
subject: HIST

description: The theory and practice of international assistance for human health issues. The roots of international development assistance following World War II; the Cold War and the so-called âWashington Consensusâ; medical humanitarian relief versus health development; health as a global public good and as a human right; ways in which the practice of health-related international assistance may evolve over the next decade. Recommended preparation: a course in global or public health. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.
title: International Assistance for Health
subject: HLTH

description: A history of artistic expression from prehistory to the Renaissance. Selected studies of architecture, sculpture, painting, metalwork, manuscript illumination, etc. Lectures in the classroom and gallery talks in the Yale University Art Gallery, Beinecke Library, and The Cloisters Museum in New York. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.
title: Introduction to History of Art: Prehistory to the Renaissance
subject: HSAR

description: A survey of Western art from the fifteenth century to the present. Introduction to both the masterpieces of artistic expression and the methods for defining and interpreting those works. Field trips to Yale museums and architectural walking tours complement the study of paintings, sculptures, architecture, and domestic and luxury arts. Readings include survey texts and original sources. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.
title: Introduction to History of Art: Renaissance to Modern
subject: HSAR

description: Relationships between politics, ideology, and aesthetics in the modern era. The intersection of visual culture and politics, from state-sanctioned art to political propaganda, to art as a medium for political activism. Ways in which images were deployed in the construction and deconstruction of state mythologies and political ideologies. Study of original artworks from the collections of the Yale University Art Gallery and the Yale Center for British Art. Includes an optional weekend field trip to museums in New York City. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.
title: Art and Politics: From Napoleon to Hitler
subject: HSAR

description: The historical relationship between art and science in the West, from the Renaissance to the present. Case studies illustrate the similarities and differences between the way artists and scientists each model the world, in the studio and the laboratory. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.
title: Art and Science
subject: HSAR

description: In-depth discussion of ten major works of Western art from the Renaissance to the modern era. Works selected both for their extraordinary qualities and for their capacity to represent a range of periods, places, media, themes, and functions. Includes visits to Yale's art museums to view corollary works of art; some attention to relevant poetry, literature, and film. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.
title: Ten Works of Western Art
subject: HSAR

description: The interplay of medicine and religion in America from the late colonial era through the twentieth century. The influence of factors such as gender, sexuality, race, ethnicity, class, regionalism, and medical and religious sectarianism. Changes over time in the fields of physiology, therapeutics, and pathology; varieties of eschatology, periods of religious awakening, and the workings of sectarian emergence and denominational evolution. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.
title: Medicine and Religion in America
subject: HSHM

description: This course is an introduction to key approaches to facilitating individual and organizational change through interactive and improvisational theater. We will examine how approaches such Sociodrama, Playback Theater, Theater of the Oppressed, and Developmental Transformations amongst other practices have been adapted to foster well-being, civic dialogue, and collaborative inquiry. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.
title: Theater and Change
subject: HUMS

description: A study of the myths of Greek and Roman gods and heroes. The literary forms, historical contexts, and cultural uses of classical mythologies. Subsequent development and reception of these myths in various cultures and media from the Renaissance to the present. Analyses of these myths over the course of the past two centuries. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.
title: Classical Mythologies
subject: HUMS

description: Introduction to classical Greek tragic drama, with close reading of selected plays in translation. Focus on the sagas of the House of Atreus and Oedipus. Structure, imagery, and theme; classical Greek stagecraft; the playwrights' responses to Homer; responses to Greek tragedy in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries. description: Offered in Auvillar, France. Open to both Yale and non-Yale students from liberal arts and fine arts backgrounds with or without prior experience.  STUDIO PRACTICE is an intensive  study of painting and drawing focusing on the dynamics of the artist's studio practice of developing and constructing work.   It is crafted for those who wish to study and experience the intimate process of personal idea imaging through the language of painting and drawing. Of great importance to the course is the development of strategies necessary for individual discovery, observation/analysis,and relational thinking. The residential program demands commitment, a strong work ethic and study within a 24/7 curriculum*.  All applicants should consult Robert Reed prior to completing the online application. Enrollment is limited to 15 participants. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Auvillar, room and board costs in France, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Interview required. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,100. Course dates: June 3 - July 3
title: Studio Practice in Painting and Drawing

description: The purpose of this intensive two-week course is to provide an overview of the objectives, research strategies, and methods of conducting patient-oriented research. Topics include competing objectives of clinical research, principles of observational studies, principles of clinical trials, principles of meta-analysis, interpretation of diagnostic tests, prognostic studies, causal inference, qualitative research methods, and decision analysis. Sessions generally combine a lecture on the topic with discussion of articles that are distributed in advance of the sessions.
requirements: Consent of instructor required. Two weeks, July 25–August 5, 2011.

description: The course provides an introduction to statistical concepts and techniques commonly encountered in medical research. Previous course work in statistics or experience with statistical packages is not a requirement. Topics to be discussed include study design, probability, comparing sample means and proportions, survival analysis, and sample size/power calculations. The computer lab incorporates lecture content into practical application by introducing the statistical software package SPSS to describe and analyze data.
requirements: Consent of instructor required. Two weeks, July 11–22, 2011.
title: Introduction to Biostatistics in Clinical Investigation

description: Offered in Siena, Italy. This five-week course combines beginning Italian with a course in English on Italian cinema focusing on Tuscany. Students will learn Italian through classes and full-immersion in the study-abroad experience (including a homestay), and will explore the representation of Tuscany through the screening and close analysis of films where the Tuscan setting has been elevated to the level of a primary thematic concern. Among the films to be considered are Night of the Shooting Stars, The First Beautiful Thing, The Adventures of Pinocchio, My Friends, Tea with Mussolini, The Sky Is Falling, Life Is Beautiful, The Man Who Will Come, Mar nero, and the Florentine episode of Paisà. Students who wish to continue with Italian are required to take a placement test in order to place into ITAL 120. Students may petition for one HU credit. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Siena, room and board costs in Italy, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. description:
Offered in Siena, Italy. The course studies a number of plays of the Italian Renaissance within the context of theoretical debates on the genre and against the realities of the social world in the fifteen and sixteen centuries Tuscany.  More precisely, it will take as its point of departure Poliziano's play and will study the impact of both Aristotle's Poetics on the theatrical premises of the theater and the Florentine intellectual life of the late 15th century. We will then read two plays of Machiavelli, the Mandragola and the Clizia by relating them to the theatrical spectacles of Italian 16th century politics (and the Prince).
Because so many plays, such as Cecchi's L'assiuolo, were performed not only for festive tides such as Carnival and Epiphany, but also be popular and courtly entertainment we will read Ariosto's Negromante in the context of the traditions of sacre rappresentazioni, and the commedia dell'arte. Taught entirely in Italian. Open to both Yale and non-Yale students. Prerequisite: ITAL 140 or 145. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Siena, room and board costs in Italy, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150.  Course dates: June 23 - July 28.
title: Italian Renaissance Theater
subject: ITAL

description: Offered in Tokyo, Japan. A broad introduction to Japanese cinema and its interrelations with modern Japanese culture. Surveys the history of Japanese film from the silent era, through the golden ages of the 1930s and the 1950s, up until the present, with particular emphasis on recent decades and films that students can relate to the Japan they experience on the streets. Cinema will be connected to various cultural phenomena, including theater, manga, television, comedy, fan subcultures, minority ethnicities, and literature. The focus will be on investigating the cultural significance of Japanese cinema, both within Japanese culture and in world film, particularly by examining how it has been located in divisions between the traditional and the modern, the national and the transnational, the individual and the group, and the private and the public. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Tokyo, costs of room and board in Tokyo, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,100. Course Dates: Course dates: July 7 - August 11.

description: Offered in Ifrane and Rabat, Morocco. The Maghrib--Morocco, Algeria, Tunisia, and Libya--has historically been a critical frontier zone linking Africa, the Middle East, and Europe.  This crossroads remains strategically important with sub-Saharan and North African migration, political Islam, Arab-Berber identity, terrorism and counter-terrorism, the Sahara question, and Mediterranean trade relationships current international concerns.  This course provides a thorough overview of North African history, the legacies of colonialism and nationalism, political systems and opposition, Islam in North Africa, and the Maghrib in the 21st century. Students will also meet with local experts, interact with Moroccan university students, and be able to do optional home stays with Moroccan families. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Morocco, room and board costs in Morocco, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. description:
Study of the management of materials, information, and financial flows in a network consisting of suppliers, manufacturers, distributors, and customers. Topics covered include logistics network configuration; risk pooling; multi-echelon inventory systems; value of information in supply chains; coordination of the supply chain using contracts and other mechanisms; distribution strategies for the supply chain; and issues related to product design. Limited enrollment. No prerequisites.

This course is offered in residence at Yale in conjunction with three other universities: Ben Gurion (Israel), Bilkent (Turkey), Maastricht (Netherlands). Six students will be admitted from each university, making up a total student body of 24. The class will then be divided into 6 teams, each team consisting of 4 students (one from each university), for discussion, writing, and presenting case studies. Yale students will meet on-campus on Mondays for lectures that will be videoconferenced to the students in the other countries. Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday meetings will be online with teammates from the other three universities. Friday meetings will be on-campus for a review of that weekâs work with fellow Yale students.

1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Course dates: June 4 - July 13.

description: Historical and analytical inquiry into the meanings of happiness and their change over time. description: Three weeks in New Haven, five weeks in St. Petersburg. This course explores the cultural history of the imperial Russian capital, founded by Peter the Great in the early eighteenth century as a window on Europe.  Since then, the city has been seen to embody all of the contradictions of Russia: East vs. West, imperial grandeur vs. the pathos of the little man, nature vs. civilization, free will vs. fate. The course considers the semiotics of Petersburg through a careful reading of selected literary texts, both prose and poetry, including Pushkin, Gogol, Dostoevsky, Blok, Bely, Gumilev, Akhmatova, Mandelstam, Khlebnikov, Mayakovsky, Kharms, and others, as well as some works of literary and cultural criticism. The classroom sessions are complimented with a rich selection of excursions and tours in and around St. Petersburg. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from St. Petersburg, costs of room and board, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with either RUSS 130/140 or RUSS S150/151. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition: see RUSS S130/140 or RUSS S 150/151.  Course Dates: June 4 - July 31.
title: Russian Culture
subject: RUSS

description: Offered in Mumbai, India. Critical engagement with contemporary Indian politics, society, culture and religion through an intensive and immersive study in Mumbai, one of the largest cities in the world. Topics include: urban poverty, urban town planning, housing problems, sanitation, cultural politics, religious and sectarian violence, caste politics, class ghettoization, communal violence, migration, urban-rural divide, Bollywood and popular culture. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from India, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For more information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,100. Course dates: June 12 - July 19.

Students will be introduced to the scientific process, including hypothesis testing, experimental design and data interpretation, through lectures, reading and discussions of the primary scientific literature. Skills development will emphasize the process of discussions of preparing written scientific reports and oral presentations highlighting effectual communication skills and the ability to interpret and display quantitative and qualitative informations. For STARS students only. Course may not be repeated for credit. 1 credit. Tuition: $3,150. June 11 - August 10.

description: Major works of social thought that articulate the core ideas of sociology. Mill, Rousseau, Marx, Durkheim, and Weber. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

description: Introduction to public health issues and health development processes that are independent of national territorial boundaries but also incorporate the health needs and priorities of individual nation states. Mechanisms and challenges involved in incorporating the World Health Organization's commitment to primary health care with principles that currently dominate the global public health agenda. Sociological critique of public health interventions. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

subject: SOCY

description: Is there a link between social identity and crime?  What is the relationship among race, gender and perceptions of criminality?  What has been the impact of increasing social diversity on forms of social control, crime and criminal justice policy?  This seminar explores these questions by examining the intersection of ethnicity, race, crime and the criminal justice system.  Students will be introduced to major, relevant criminological and sociological concepts, theories and debates.  Class discussions will address contemporary social problems such as racial profiling, disproportionate punishment, mass incarceration and unequal justice.  Examples draw principally from the American but also from the British context, providing a comparative perspective. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.
title: Multiculturalism and the Ordered Society
subject: SOCY

description: The sociology of deviance and its relationship to inequality. Focus on contemporary society, with some attention to the history of aberrant identities. Sociological theories of deviance; social inequality as the consequence of deviance and vice versa; the construction of aberrant identities; ways in which individuals and groups cope with the stigma of deviance. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.

description: Offered in Ifrane and Rabat, Morocco. The Maghrib--Morocco, Algeria, Tunisia, and Libya--has historically been a critical frontier zone linking Africa, the Middle East, and Europe.  This crossroads remains strategically important with sub-Saharan and North African migration, political Islam, Arab-Berber identity, terrorism and counter-terrorism, the Sahara question, and Mediterranean trade relationships current international concerns.  This course provides a thorough overview of North African history, the legacies of colonialism and nationalism, political systems and opposition, Islam in North Africa, and the Maghrib in the 21st century. Students will also meet with local experts, interact with Moroccan university students, and be able to do optional home stays with Moroccan families. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Morocco, room and board costs in Morocco, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,100. Course dates: June 23 - July 28.
title: Society and Politics of North Africa
subject: SOCY

description: Offered in Dubrovnik, Croatia. Multidisciplinary study from antiquity to modernity. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Dubrovnik, room and board costs in Croatia, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Must be taken in conjunction with HIST S299. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,050. Course dates: July 2 - August 3.

description: For students who wish to begin study of the Spanish language. Development of basic skills in understanding, speaking, reading, and writing through a functional approach to the teaching of spanish grammar. Includes an introduction to the cultures (traditions, art, literature, music) of the Spanish-speaking world. Audio-visual materials are incorporated into class sessions. Conducted in Spanish. To be followed by SPAN S120.  Credit only on completion of SPAN S120. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.
title: Elementary Spanish I
subject: SPAN

description: Further development of understanding, speaking, reading, and writing skills. Class sessions incorporate short authentic texts in Spanish, audiovisual materials, and film. Cultural topics of the Spanish-speaking world (traditions, art, literature, music) are included. Conducted in Spanish. After SPAN S110 or in accordance with placement results. Admits to SPAN 130 or 145. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.
title: Elementary Spanish II
subject: SPAN

description: 4 weeks in New Haven, 4 weeks abroad. Development of proficiency in listening, speaking, reading, and writing through communicative activities rather than as a sequence of linguistic units. Use of authentic Spanish language texts, films, and videos; presentation of cultural topics. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from the site, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Must be taken in conjunction with SPAN S140 (in Bilbao CRN 30239, in Quito CRN 30242) and S248 or S249 (in Bilbao SPAN S248 CRN 30240 Spain, 1936 to the Present, or in Quito SPAN S249 CRN 30243 Ecuador Pre-Columbian to Present). Prerequisite: SPAN 120 (Elementary Spanish II) or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,300. Course dates: June 4 - July 28.
title: Intermediate Spanish I
subject: SPAN

description: Offered in Buenos Aires, Argentina. This course explores the dynamics of figurative and theatrical language through close reading of early and contemporary Spanish and Latin American dramatic texts. The selected plays reflect on the topics of gender, identity, love, politics, torture and violence. Students participate in an acting workshop and attend live performances of Argentine theater. Prerequisite: SPAN 150 or equivalent. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Buenos Aires, room and board costs in Argentina, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150.  Course dates: June 2 - July 7.
title: Theater and Poetry Workshop
subject: SPAN

description: 4 weeks in New Haven, 4 weeks in Bilbao, Spain. Analysis and discussion of the historical, social, and cultural development of Spain from the Civil War to the present. Use of a variety of materials, including literary texts, essays, film, television, music, and visual arts. Classes will be held in the headquarters of the University of Deusto, located opposite the statuary and facing the Guggenheim Museum. Founded in 1886, the university continues to be one of the most important institutions of higher education of the Basque Country and Spain. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Bilbao, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Must be taken in conjunction with SPAN S130 and S140. Prerequisite: SPAN 120 (Elementary Spanish II) or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition: see SPAN S130/140. Course dates: June 4 - July 28.
title: Spain, 1936 to the Present: History, Literature and Culture
subject: SPAN

description: 4 weeks in New Haven, 4 weeks in Quito, Ecuador. Analysis and discussion of the historical, social, and cultural development of Ecuador from Pre-Columbian times to the present. Presented through a variety of materials (literary texts, essays, films, music, visual arts). Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Quito, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Must be taken in conjunction with SPAN S130 and S140. Prerequisite: SPAN 120 (Elementary Spanish II) or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition: see SPAN S130/S140. Course dates: June 4 - July 28.
title: Ecuador from Pre-Columbian Times to Present
subject: SPAN

description: An examination of forces shaping American cities and strategies for dealing with them. Topics include housing, commercial development, parks, zoning, urban renewal, landmark preservation, new towns, and suburbs. Includes games, simulated problems, fieldwork, lectures, and discussion as well as field trips in New Haven and to New York City. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.
title: Introduction to the Study of the City
subject: STCY

description: Offered at the Swahili Resource Centre in Mombasa, Kenya. Refinement of students' speaking, listening, reading, and writing skills. Prepares students for further work in literary, language, and cultural studies as well as for a functional use of Kiswahili. Study of structure and vocabulary is based on a variety of texts from traditional and popular culture. Emphasis on command of idiomatic usage and stylistic nuance.  Must be taken in conjunction with SWAH S140. Prerequisite: SWAH 120b (Elementary Kiswahili II) or equivalent. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. Additional costs: $2,500 room and board in Kenya. Students are responsible for arranging travel and paying for airfare to and from Mombasa, as well as passport, visa, inoculations, and similar expenses. For further information contact the instructor at 203.432.9902 or at ann.biersteker@yale.edu.  Please also see www.yale.edu/macmillan/african. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $2,500. Course dates: June 3 - July 29.
title: Intermediate Kiswahili I
subject: SWAH

description: Offered at the Swahili Resource Centre in Mombasa, Kenya. Refinement of students' speaking, listening, reading, and writing skills. Prepares students for further work in literary, language, and cultural studies as well as for a functional use of Kiswahili. Study of structure and vocabulary is based on a variety of texts from traditional and popular culture. Emphasis on command of idiomatic usage and stylistic nuance.  Must be taken in conjunction with SWAH S130. Prerequisite: SWAH 130 (Intermediate Kiswahili I) or equivalent. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. Additional costs: $2,500 room and board in Kenya. Students are responsible for arranging travel and paying for airfare to and from Mombasa, as well as passport, visa, inoculations, and similar expenses. For further information contact the instructor at 203.432.9902 or at ann.biersteker@yale.edu.  Please also see www.yale.edu/macmillan/african. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $2,500. Course dates: June 3 - July 29.
title: Intermediate Kiswahili II
subject: SWAH

description: Offered in Mombasa, Kenya. Development of fluency through readings and discussions on contemporary topics in Kiswahili, including its origins and spread to different parts of Eastern and Central Africa. The role of Kiswahili in addressing issues such as health and the environment. Introduction to literary criticism in Kiswahili. Materials include Kiswahili oral literature, prose, poetry, and plays, as well as texts drawn from popular and political culture. Prerequisite: SWAH 140b or equivalent. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Kenya, room and board costs, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 2 Credits. Tuition $5,000. Course dates: June 2 - July 14.
title: Advanced Kiswahili
subject: SWAH

description: This course is an introduction to key approaches to facilitating individual and organizational change through interactive and improvisational theater. We will examine how approaches such Sociodrama, Playback Theater, Theater of the Oppressed, and Developmental Transformations amongst other practices have been adapted to foster well-being, civic dialogue, and collaborative inquiry. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.
title: Theater and Change
subject: THST

description: Introduction to classical Greek tragic drama, with close reading of selected plays in translation. Focus on the sagas of the House of Atreus and Oedipus. Structure, imagery, and theme; classical Greek stagecraft; the playwrights' responses to Homer; responses to Greek tragedy in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries. Includes screenings of film adaptations of the plays. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.
title: Greek Tragedy in Translation
subject: THST

description: Intensive study of five major playwrights: Ibsen, Strindberg, Chekhov, Brecht, and Beckett. Additional readings in related theater theory. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.
title: Modern European Drama
subject: THST

description: Interdisciplinary exploration of the gendering of food production, preparation, and consumption in cross-cultural perspective. Topics include agricultural practices, cooking, pasteurization, kitchen technology, food storage, home economics, hunger, anorexia, breast-feeding, meals, and ethnic identity. Class visits to Peabody Museum, Beinecke Library, Yale Farm and Yale University Art Gallery. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.
title: Women, Food and Culture
subject: WGSS

description: Introduction to scholarship on the anthropology of reproduction. Focus on reproductive technologies such as contraceptives, prenatal diagnostics, childbirth technologies, abortion, assisted reproduction, and reproductive technologies that engender harm, such as sex selection and female circumcision. The globalization of reproductive technologies, including social, cultural, legal, and ethical responses. Recommended preparation: ANTH 110b or equivalent. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,150. Session B: July 9 - August 10.
title: Reproductive Technologies
subject: WGSS

description: Study of works that have as their theme gay and lesbian experience and identity since the late nineteenth century. Works include fiction and autobiographical texts, historical and sociological materials, texts on queer theory, and films. Focus on modes of representing sexuality and on the intersections between sexuality and race, ethnicity, class, gender, and nationality. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.
title: Introduction to LGBT Studies
subject: WGSS

description: The genre of the graphic memoir examined from literary, visual, historical, critical, and creative perspectives. Approaches to the history of the genre; theory of comics and popular culture; theory of memoir; cultural and media studies. Books will include:  Fun Home, by Alison Bechdel; Barefoot Gen, by Keiji Nakazawa; Safe Area Gorazde, by Joe Sacco; Persepolis, by Marjane Satrapi; Stitches, by David Small; Metamouse, by Art Spiegelman; In the Shadow of No Towers, by Art Spiegelman; American Widow, by Alissa Torres, and Understanding Comics, by Scott McCloud. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,150. Session A: June 4 - July 6.
title: Graphic Memoir
subject: WGSS
